title: Data Critique
text:
The original sources for our dataset, the Gender Data Portal, are national governments and major international organizations that collect official disaggregated gender statistics. These sources include organizations like national statistical offices, labor and health ministries, and agencies responsible for education and population data. At the international level, much of the data comes from the United Nations (UNDP, UNICEF, UN Women), UNESCO, the International Labour Organization (ILO), the World Health Organization (WHO), and the International Monetary Fund (IMF). These organizations gather standardized data from member countries, which the World Bank then combines and organizes in the Gender Data Portal so people can easily compare information across countries.
The World Bank Group is the organization that funded the creation of the dataset. More specifically, the World Bank’s Gender Group and the Development Economics Data Group compiled this data and updated it 4 times a year. In addition, a combination of multi-donor trust funds, such as the Umbrella Facility for Gender Equality, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, etc, that have donated individual contributions for years.
The dataset from 2000-2023 illuminated the complex relationship between gender equality, education, health and economic development of different countries through the following variable categories:

Human Capital & Health: Indicators related to population health, healthcare access, and overall human capital development. These variables reflect overall human capital through the female-specific human capital index
Women’s Autonomy and Reproductive Health: These variables measure women’s empowerment in personal and reproductive decision-making and assess the degree of autonomy, reproductive rights, and access to reproductive health services among women.
Economic Indicators: These variables focus on the broader economic environment, income distribution, and the inclusiveness of economic growth.
Population & Demographic: The demographic variables provide basic structural information about a country’s population, including total population size and the proportion of females.
Education: Education indicators reflect gender parity and access to schooling across different levels. These variables provide insights into gender equality in educational attainment and investment in human capital formation.
Labor Force & Education Level: Labor force indicators describe the distribution of educational attainment among working-age populations, disaggregated by gender.
Gender Equality & Institutional Factors: These variables include institutional-level measures of gender equality

Variables such as Human Capital Index (HCI), literacy rates, and school enrollment gender parity depicted the pattern of females getting education and their success. Index related with prenatal care, reproductive decision-making, and out-of-pocket health expenditures highlighted the fact that in many parts of the world, women are facing medical and health related inequalities systematically. The average growth of GDP, distribution of income and rate of poverty are also essential economic indicators when seeing these datasets. Because they examined how gender and education can be related with the level of income and social mobility. Together the dataset contributed a valuable perspective towards factors in policy making, social development and the differences between these countries when facing similar problems in education and health inequalities of women around the globe.
Though this dataset does contain a large quantity of gender related and relevant indicators such as time series data from multiple countries and meta data about the data availability and gaps, it is not entirely inclusive. The datasets cannot reveal coverage of all countries and years between 2000-2023 due to many missing indicators. Due to this lack of data, some high income or small income countries may be severely or slightly underrepresented. We cannot assume that this dataset provides full global coverage. Additionally, people who are considered women, but are not counted on the country level of who is defined as women cannot be portrayed by this data set. For example, women who do not have gender defined on their birth certificate would be excluded from this dataset. Furthermore, non-binary gender identities are absent and can be completely discarded in the portrayal of this set.
Because this data comes from the World Bank Group, which pulls its data from each country’s statistical databases, this makes our data susceptible to the ideologies of each country. For example, as our topic is focused on gender inequality and justice, the dataset alone does not describe how each country determines and explores gender identity or who they count in their statistics as “female,” for example. In a similar manner, our dataset has many variables relating to youth education rates. However, the dataset emphasizes formal forms of education, like primary school or trade school, and leaves out informal education which may be more common in less developed countries. Our data alone outlines gender inequality to be a measurable issue that may depend on the development index of each country, but we know that this is not necessarily the case.
In addition, it is important to recognize that the World Bank and other contributing international organizations shape the very ontology of this dataset through their own institutional and political frameworks. By emphasizing measurable, standardized indicators that align with development goals such as economic growth or educational attainment, these organizations implicitly define what counts as “progress” or “equality.” This framing can marginalize alternative understandings of gender justice that emphasize cultural, social, or local forms of empowerment. It is up to us to identify the narrative and meaning behind this data to explore what is truly happening with these issues of gender inequality.

title: Beyond the Classroom: How Education Shapes Women’s Health and Futures
text:
Digital Humanities 101 Project - Digital Divas
Group Members: Cynthia Du, Claire Hayashida, Tom Liu, Allison Lynn, Montserrat Munoz-Garcia, Koji Schafer

title: About
text:
Cynthia Du  Hi! I’m Cynthia Du, a 4th year Stats + Data Science and Cognitive Science w/ a Specialization in Computing double major! My role as the product manager is to ensure that our project is flowing smoothly and communication between the team is going well. In addition, I work with the rest of the team to generate the information needed for the site!



Claire Hayashida  Hi! I’m Cynthia Du, a 4th year Statistics + Data Science and Cognitive Science w/ a Specialization in Computing double major from Denver, CO! My role as the product manager is to ensure that our project flows smoothly and communication between the team is going well. In addition, I work with the rest of the team to generate the information needed for the site!



Allison Lynn  I’m Allison, a senior Statistics and Data Science Major from San Diego, California. I am the web designer, responsible for creating the website and designing it! I enjoy web designing so much and can’t wait to portray our argument and project through this website!



Tom Liu  Hi, I’m Tom, a third year transfer student majoring in Sociology with a minor in digital humanities from Changchun, Northeastern China. My role as the content developer is to have written analysis according to the data visualizations and making sure that the narratives from our group is consistent and coherent. I will also collaborate with other team members during the final stage of the project to oversee the editing process.



Koji Schafer  Hi, I’m Koji Schafer, a third year International Development Studies Major and Global Health Minor from Culver City, California. My role as the editor is to oversee the overall“look” of the project to ensure consistent design, readability, and accessibility. Ensures that all elements of the project are present and edits the narrative to correct organizational, spelling, and grammatical errors. In addition, I will eagerly collaborate with the rest of the team to successfully execute a meaningful body of work.



Montserra Munoz-Garcia  Hi, I’m Monse, a third year student majoring in Cognitive Science with a minor in Digital Humanities. In my role as data visualization specialist, is to ensure that chosen data is in the right format and is fine-tuned.

title: About
text:
Our Project
We are a team of UCLA students investigating how women’s education shapes health outcomes across countries at varying stages of development. Our research explores how education serves as a critical determinant of women’s health by influencing fertility behavior, access to healthcare, and overall knowledge about reproductive and maternal health. We argue that higher levels of education among women correlate with lower fertility rates, as education often delays marriage and childbearing while increasing awareness and use of family planning methods. Moreover, education enhances women’s ability to navigate healthcare systems such as improving access to prenatal and postnatal care, child immunization, and preventive services.
Beyond access, education empowers women with the knowledge to make informed health decisions, challenge harmful cultural norms, and advocate for their own well-being. By comparing data across countries at different stages of economic and social development, our project seeks to highlight how investments in women’s education not only improve individual health outcomes but also generate broader societal benefits, including reduced maternal mortality, healthier families, and more sustainable population growth. We believe this will allow us to produce a meaningful and inclusive project that will enable individuals around the world to understand our research question.
